item.title: Report X-2024061051
item.description:
Report X-2024061051

Identified by scraper @ 2024-06-24T15:13:21+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-15
  • City: CONCORD
  • State: NC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: The package was brought to the QA department after a manager located this in a tote at the back of the building in the bulk truck area. We inspected the package and found that 1 of the 2 bottles had a loose cap and the entire contents of one of the bottles spilled out inside the box which contaminated the entire package. We made sure to isolate this damage in a lined hazmat tote and moved it to the hazmat cage.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: CALL WAS MADE TO THE DMP CAGE ABOUT A LEAKING HAZMAT. DESIGNATED RESPONDER FOUND PACKAGE ON THE FLOOR WITH THE BOTTOM WET. WHEN OPENED, 1 OF THE GLASS CONTAINERS WAS BROKEN. FOLLOWING ALL PROPER RESPONDER METHODS, PACKAGE WAS SECURED AND RETURNED TO THE DMP CAGE TO BE PROCESSED.

item.title: Report E-2024060476
item.description:
Report E-2024060476

Identified by scraper @ 2024-06-24T15:13:21+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-29
  • City: CHARLOTTE
  • State: NC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: It was reported that due to a forklift puncture, approximately 4-cups of ZIM PIC Special (hazardous - UN1090) was released. The caller stated that the released product was contained to the dock floor and evaporated. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller and they felt comfortable cleaning the release donning the proper PPE per SDS. The damaged drum and remaining product was placed into an 85-gallon poly drum and staged in OS&D. There were no drains, soils or waterways reported to have been impacted by the release.
